children.value: In this section, we will complete the set of exploit exercises known as Protostar. The first challenge is called Stack0. The idea is to change an internal variable in a running program from the command line. The technique involves overflowing a buffer to overwrite the contents of the internal variable. The link is shown below.

We will perform this exercise using the ARM32 platform instead of the original i386 platform. The C code should run the same way, while the underlying assembly code is very different. We will explore the similarities as well as the differences between the two platforms.
We start with the vulnerable C Program
. The program is vulnerable because the
function does not have any bounds checking. In other words, it will take whatever amount of data is given to it and put this data into the
argument, even if the amount of data exceeds the storage space allocated for
If a properly coded payload is input into the
variable and even other variables. In this case, the variable we wish to overwrite is called

Program execution in the command line
Clearly, we need to disassemble the program to understand its behavior and figure out how we can change the
variable. We enter a breakpoint at
allows us to get to the beginning of the main function’s assembly code. Otherwise, breaking at
would only reach the beginning of the variable assignments, missing the important stack setup.

Creating the Payload to Overwrite the Variable

children.label: Creating the Payload to Overwrite the Variable modified

children.value: We will create a Python script to build a payload. This payload will contain 64+4 characters, which is the 68 bytes necessary to completely overwrite the variable
Python program to generate payload to input into
The goal of this program is to generate 66 bytes. The reason it is not 68 bytes is because we need to account for the carriage return (CR) character that Python’s
statement appends to the end. Below is the output of
Layout of the Stack in Program

children.label: Layout of the Stack in Program stack0.c After mov DWORD PTR [esp], eax Instruction

children.value: The table below illustrates the layout of the stack once
We have now successfully created a payload and executed the vulnerable program. By carefully stepping through the disassembly and manipulating the stack, we have been able to overwrite the
variable and achieve the intended outcome. The process demonstrates how buffer overflows can be used to manipulate the behavior of a program by controlling stack
